chapter.htmlHeader: Scenario: Progestogen-only pill
chapter.summary: Covers the use of the progestogen-only pill (POP), including the available products; when to start it; the efficacy; how to manage common problems (such as missed pills); the advantages, disadvantages, risks, possible adverse effects and key drug interactions; and follow up requirements for this method of contraception.
chapter.htmlStringContent: From age 13 years to 60 years (Female).

chapters.fullItemName: Have I got the right topic?

subChapters.htmlHeader: Starting a progestogen-only pill
subChapters.htmlStringContent: <!-- begin item eb0afaac-99ab-4304-aa8e-89a4e015480f --><!-- end item eb0afaac-99ab-4304-aa8e-89a4e015480f -->

subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I assess a woman who is considering starting the progestogen-only pill?
subChapters.htmlStringContent: • For information on assessing a woman considering starting a progestogen-only pill, see the CKS topic on Contraception - assessment.

subChapters.htmlHeader: What types of progestogen-only pills (POPs) are available?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• The progestogen-only pills licensed in the UK are:
    • Norgeston® (levonorgestrel 30 micrograms).
    • Noriday®, Micronor® (norethisterone 350 micrograms).
    • Cerazette®, Cerelle®, Feanolla®, Aizea® (desogestrel 75 micrograms).
    • A generic desogestrel 75 micrograms.
  • Progestogen-only pills should be taken daily at the same time each day for 28 days, with no pill-free interval.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Which progestogen-only pill should I offer first-line?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Any licensed progestogen-only pill (POP) may be used first-line.
  • However, possible adverse effects and/or rules about missed pills differ between products and this may affect their acceptability. For example:
    • Irregular bleeding (particularly in the first few months) may be more of a problem with the desogestrel-only pill than with other POPs.
    • If the woman is unable to consistently take her pill at the same time every day, or within 3 hours of the usual pill time, consider prescribing desogestrel, which should be taken at the same time every day or within 12 hours of the usual pill time.

subChapters.htmlHeader: What quantity of POP should I prescribe?
subChapters.htmlStringContent: • Prescribe 3–6 months' supply of progestogen-only pills at the first visit and up to 12 months' supply at follow up visits.

subChapters.htmlHeader: When should a woman start a progestogen-only pill?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
Specific advice for women who are amenorrhoeic, postpartum and breastfeeding, postpartum and not breastfeeding, post-termination of pregnancy, or post-miscarriage is summarized in the section on Amenorrhoea, postpartum, termination of pregnancy, or miscarriage. 

  • If the woman is not currently using a regular method of contraception or using a barrier method (such as condoms):
    • Start the progestogen-only pill (POP) on days 1 to 5 of the menstrual cycle.
      • No additional contraception is required.
    • If the POP is started at any other time in the menstrual cycle, and it is reasonably certain that the women is not pregnant and there has been no risk of conception (off-label use):
      • Advise the woman to avoid sexual intercourse or use a barrier method of contraception (such as condoms) for 48 hours after starting the pill.
    • If pregnancy cannot be excluded and the women wishes to start a hormonal method of contraception without delay:
      • Assess the need for emergency contraception (EC) and prescribe if necessary. For more information, see the CKS topic on Contraception - emergency.
      • Prescribe the POP.
      • Advise the woman to have a pregnancy test no sooner 3 weeks after the last episode of unprotected sexual intercourse (UPSI).
  • If the woman is starting the POP after oral EC:
    • For levonorgestrel, start the POP immediately, and advise the woman to avoid sexual intercourse or use a barrier method of contraception (such as condoms) for the first 2 days.
    • For ulipristal acetate, start the POP 5 days after taking oral ulipristal acetate, and advise the woman to avoid sexual intercourse or use a barrier method of contraception (such as condoms) during this time and for the first 2 days of taking the POP.
    • Advise the woman to have a pregnancy test no sooner than 3 weeks after the last episode of UPSI.
  • If the woman is changing from another POP:
    • Start the POP at any time
    • No additional contraception is required.
  • If the woman is changing from a combined hormonal contraceptive (CHC): 
    • Start the POP on days 1 to 7 of the hormone-free interval (day 1 is the optimal time to switch).
      • No additional contraception is required.
    • If the POP is started on week 1 of normal CHC use:
      • Advise the woman to abstain from sex or use a barrier method of contraception (such as condoms) for 48 hours after starting the POP.
      • If UPSI has occurred in the hormone-free interval, or week 1, continue the CHC for 7 consecutive days before switching.
      • If CHC cannot be continued, switch to the POP immediately. Consider the need for EC and a pregnancy test if pregnancy cannot be excluded. 
    • If the POP is started on weeks 2–3 of CHC use:
      • No additional precautions are required if the method has been used correctly for the previous 7 days. 
  • If the woman is changing from an injectable progestogen-only contraceptive:
    • Start the POP up to 14 weeks after the last injection.
      • No additional contraception is required.
    • If the POP is started more than 14 weeks after the last injection. 
      • Advise the woman to abstain from sex or use a barrier method of contraception (such as condoms) for 48 hours after starting the POP.
      • Consider the need for EC, and a pregnancy test if pregnancy cannot be excluded.
  • If the woman is changing from the progestogen-only implant:
    • Start the POP up to 3 years after insertion of the implant. 
      • No additional contraception is required.
    • If the POP is started more than 3 years after insertion:
      • Advise the woman to abstain from sex or use a barrier method of contraception (such as condoms) for 48 hours after starting the POP.
      • Consider the need for EC, and a pregnancy test if pregnancy cannot be excluded.
  • If the woman is changing from a copper intrauterine device (Cu-IUD)
    • Start the POP at least 2 days before removal of the Cu-IUD.
      •  No additional contraception is required.
    • If the POP is started on the day of the IUD removal, provided that there has been no UPSI in the preceding 7 days. 
      • Advise the woman to avoid sexual intercourse or use a barrier method of contraception (such as condoms) for 48 hours after starting the POP.
      • Consider the need for EC, and a pregnancy test if pregnancy cannot be excluded.
  • If the woman is changing from a levonorgestrel intrauterine system (LNG-IUS) 
    • Start the POP at least 2 days before removal of the LNG-IUS.
      • No additional contraception is required.
    • If the POP is started on the day of removal of the LNG-IUS.
      • Advise the woman to avoid sexual intercourse or use a barrier method of contraception (such as condoms) for 48 hours after starting the POP.
      • Consider the need for EC, and a pregnancy test if pregnancy cannot be excluded.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Amenorrhoea, postpartum, termination of pregnancy, or miscarriage
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• If the woman is amenorrhoeic:
    • Start the progestogen-only pill (POP) at any time, provided it is reasonably certain that the woman is not pregnant.
      • Additional contraception is required for 48 hours.
      • Consider the need for emergency contraception, and advise the woman to take a pregnancy test no sooner than 3 weeks after the last episode of unprotected sexual intercourse (UPSI). 
  • If the woman is postpartum (whether breastfeeding or not):
    • Start the POP at any time.
      • If started before day 21 postpartum, no additional contraception is required.
    • If started after day 21 postpartum, advise the woman to abstain from sex or use a barrier method of contraception (such as condoms) for 48 hours after starting the POP, unless she is using the lactational amenorrhoea method (LAM) of contraception. See the CKS topic on Contraception - natural family planning, for more information on the LAM.
      • Consider the need for emergency contraception (EC), and advise the woman to take a pregnancy test no sooner than 3 weeks after the last episode of UPSI. 
  • If the woman has had a miscarriage or termination of pregnancy: 
    • If gestation is less than 24 weeks, ideally, start the POP on the day of a miscarriage, surgical termination, or first part of a medical termination.
      • If the POP is started within 5 days of miscarriage or termination, no additional contraception is required.
    • If the POP is started 5 days or more after miscarriage or termination, advise the woman to abstain from sex or use a barrier method of contraception (such as condoms) for 48 hours.
      • Consider the need for EC, and advise the woman to take a pregnancy test no sooner than 3 weeks after the last episode of UPSI. 
    • If gestation is 24 weeks or more, treat as for a woman who is postpartum.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Excluding pregnancy
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Health professionals can be ‘reasonably certain’ that a woman is not pregnant if there are no signs or symptoms of pregnancy and one or more of the following criteria are met. The woman:
    • Has not had sexual intercourse since the last normal menses.
    • Has used a reliable method of contraception correctly and consistently.
    • Is within the first 7 days of the onset of a normal menstrual period.
    • Is within 4 weeks postpartum for non-breastfeeding women.
    • Is within the first 7 days post-termination of pregnancy, or miscarriage.
    • Is fully or nearly fully breastfeeding, amenorrhoeic, and less than 6 months postpartum.
    • A pregnancy test is performed no sooner than 3 weeks since the last episode of unprotected sexual intercourse (UPSI) and is negative.

subChapters.htmlHeader: What is the mechanism of action of progestogen-only pills (POPs)?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Progestogen-only pills (POPs) have five independent modes of action:
    • Suppression of ovulation — this occurs in varying degrees (97% in women taking desogestrel and about 60% in woman taking levonorgestrel [Norgeston®]).
    • Suppression of mid-cycle peaks of luteinizing hormone and follicle-stimulating hormone.
    • Production of 'hostile, blocked' mucus, resulting in poor sperm penetration.
    • Reduction in the number and size of endometrial glands and inhibition of progesterone receptor synthesis in the endometrium, preventing implantation.
    • Reduction in the activity of cilia in the Fallopian tube.
    • POPs prevent conception (even when ovulation is not suppressed) through various combinations of these mechanisms, with great inter-individual and intra-individual variation.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
Types of progestogen only pill
  • These recommendations are based on the Faculty of Sexual and Reproductive Healthcare (FSRH) clinical guideline Progestogen-only pills [FSRH, 2015a] and the British National Formulary [BNF 71, 2016].
Quantity of progestogen-only pill (POP) to prescribe
  • The FRSH recommends prescribing up to 12 months' supply at the first visit, however CKS recommends initially prescribing 3–6 months' supply until the first follow-up visit, to ensure the POP is suitable before prescribing a larger quantity.
When to start
  • These recommendations are based on the Faculty of Sexual and Reproductive Healthcare (FSRH) clinical guidelines Progestogen-only pills [FSRH, 2015a], UK Medical Eligibility Criteria for contraceptive use [FSRH, 2016], Quick starting contraception [FSRH, 2010a], Contraception after pregnancy [FSRH, 2017b], and a statement from the FSRH clinical effectiveness unit [FSRH, 2015b].
Mechanism of action

  • This information is based on the Faculty of Sexual and Reproductive Healthcare (FSRH) clinical guideline, Progestogen-only pills [FSRH, 2015a].

subChapters.htmlHeader: What information and advice should I give a woman who is considering using a progestogen-only pill (POP)?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Discuss:
    • The mechanism of action of the progestogen-only pill (POP).
    • The advantages and disadvantages of the POP.
    • The contraceptive efficacy of the POP.
    • What happens when the POP is stopped — advise the woman that normal fertility returns as soon as the POP is stopped.
  • Give advice on:
    • The importance of taking the pill regularly at a time of day that will aid adherence.
    • Missed pills.
    • Vomiting or diarrhoea after taking the POP.
    • Possible adverse effects (such as unscheduled bleeding) of the POP.
    • The possibility of drug interactions.
      • Advise the woman to check with a healthcare professional before starting any new drug treatment (including herbal remedies).
  • Also:
    • Provide written information on the POP. The Family Planning Association provides a useful leaflet with information for women using the POP. 
    • Offer verbal and/or written advice on long-acting reversible contraception (copper intrauterine device, levonorgestrel intrauterine system, progestogen-only injectables, progestogen-only implant, and the combined vaginal ring). See the CKS topics on Contraception - IUS/IUD and Contraception - combined hormonal methods for more information on these methods of contraception.

subChapters.htmlHeader: What missed pill advice should I give?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Check which progestogen-only pill (POP) the woman is taking and the time since the last pill was taken.
    • For the desogestrel pill — a pill is missed if she is more than 12 hours late (that is more than 36 hours since taking the last pill).
    • For all other progestogen-only pills — a pill is missed if she is more than 2 hours late (that is more than 26 hours since taking the last pill).
  • If the woman has missed any POP, she should:
    • Take a pill as soon as possible.
    • Take the next pill at the normal time. This may mean taking two pills in 24 hours (the missed pill and the next one at the usual time).
    • Use a barrier method of contraception (such as condoms) for the next 48 hours, unless she is less than 6 months postpartum, fully breastfeeding, and amenorrhoeic.
  • Consider prescribing emergency contraception if unprotected sexual intercourse has taken place after the missed pill and within 48 hours of restarting the POP. For more information, see the CKS topic on Contraception - emergency.

subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I manage a woman who becomes pregnant whilst using the progestogen-only pill?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• If a woman is found to be pregnant whilst using the progestogen-only pill (POP) and she wishes to continue with the pregnancy:
    • Advise her to stop taking the POP.
    • Inform her that there is no evidence of harm to the baby or the mother if pregnancy occurs while using the POP.
    • Be alert to the possibility of an ectopic pregnancy. For more information, see the CKS topic on Ectopic pregnancy.

subChapters.htmlHeader: What advice should I give a woman taking progestogen-only pills about vomiting or diarrhoea?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• If a woman vomits within 2 hours of pill taking, another pill should be taken as soon as possible. If the subsequent pill is missed, she should be given the instructions for missed pills.
  • If vomiting or diarrhoea persists for more than 24 hours, advise her to:
    • Follow the instructions for missed pills, counting each day of vomiting and/or diarrhoea as a missed pill.
    • Avoid sexual intercourse or use a barrier method of contraception (such as condoms) during the illness and for 48 hours afterwards.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
Information and advice
  • These recommendations are based on the Faculty of Sexual and Reproductive Healthcare (FSRH) clinical guideline, Progestogen-only pills [FSRH, 2015a].
Missed pill

  • These recommendations are based on the Faculty of Sexual and Reproductive Healthcare (FSRH) clinical guideline Progestogen-only pills [FSRH, 2015a].

Pregnancy

  • These recommendations are based on the Faculty of Sexual and Reproductive Healthcare (FSRH) clinical guideline Progestogen-only pills [FSRH, 2015a], and the manufacturer's Summary of Product Characteristics [ABPI, 2015a; ABPI, 2016a].

Vomiting or diarrhoea
  • These recommendations are based on the Faculty of Sexual and Reproductive Healthcare (FSRH) clinical guideline Drug interactions with hormonal contraception [FSRH, 2017a].

subChapters.htmlHeader: What are the advantages and disadvantages of progestogen-only pills (POPs)?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
Advantages
  • The progestogen-only pill (POP) is very effective when taken correctly and is more effective than barrier methods of contraception. 
  • Sex need not be interrupted to use the POP.
  • It can be used by women for whom the combined oral contraceptive is not suitable.
  • It may reduce the risk of endometrial cancer.
  • Desogestrel may be beneficial in managing dysmenorrhoea.
  • Normal fertility returns when the POP is stopped.

Disadvantages

  • Pills must be taken at the same time each day, or within 3 hours, except for the desogestrel-only pill, which must be taken within 12 hours to be effective.
  • Adverse effects (such as unscheduled bleeding and breast tenderness) may be experienced by some women when they first start a POP, however these are transient. 
  • The POP does not protect against sexually transmitted infections (STIs). People at risk of STIs should be advised to also use a barrier method of contraception (such as condoms). For more information, see the CKS topic on Contraception - barrier methods and spermicides.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent: This information is based on the Faculty of Sexual and Reproductive Healthcare (FSRH) clinical guideline, Progestogen-only pills [FSRH, 2015a] and the manufacturer's Summary of Product Characteristics [ABPI, 2015a; ABPI, 2016a].

subChapters.htmlHeader: What are the possible risks and adverse effects of progestogen-only pills (POPs)?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Menstrual irregularities — changes in bleeding patterns are common. For more information, see the section on unscheduled bleeding.
  • Breast tenderness — this is usually transient. However, if it is persistently troublesome, consider changing to another progestogen-only pill (POP), or to another contraceptive method. See the CKS topic on Contraception - assessment for information on other contraceptive methods.
  • Ovarian cysts — POP use is associated with around 30% higher risk of developing spontaneously reversible ovarian cysts.
  • Ectopic pregnancy — there is a small increased risk of ectopic pregnancy in women using POPs (with the exception of desogestrel), but the absolute risk is lower than if not using contraception. Around 1 in 10 pregnancies that occur may be ectopic.
  • Increased cancer risk — there is a possible increased risk of breast cancer with the use of POPs. However, this risk is very small compared with the overall risk of developing breast cancer, and 10 years after stopping the POP, the risk of developing breast cancer is the same as for women who have never used hormonal contraceptives.
    • Compared with women who have never used the POP:
      • In 10,000 women who use the POP for up to 5 years and stop by the age of 20 years, less than 1 additional case of breast cancer will be diagnosed up to 10 years afterwards.
      • In 10,000 women who use the POP for up to 5 years and stop by the age of 30 years, about 2–3 extra cases of breast cancer (in addition to 44 cases per 10,000 women in this age group that have never used oral contraceptives) will be diagnosed up to 10 years afterwards.
      • In 10,000 women who use the POP for up to 5 years and stop by the age of 40 years, about 10 extra cases of breast cancer (in addition to 160 cases per 10,000 women in this age group that have never used oral contraceptives) will be diagnosed up to 10 years afterwards.
    • There is no evidence for any increased risk of other cancers and the POP may reduce the risk of endometrial cancer.
  • There is no evidence that the POP causes:
    • Depression and mood changes (although mood changes have been reported. Panic attacks have also been reported in women using desogestrel).
    • Headache.
    • Libido changes (however this is listed in the manufacturer's Summary of Product Characteristics).
    • Cardiovascular disease, including myocardial infarction, venous thromboembolism, and stroke.
    • Weight changes (although this has been reported in women using the POP in clinical trials).

[BJCP, 2018]

subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I manage unscheduled bleeding in a woman using a progestogen-only pill?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Exclude and/or manage:
    • Situations which could compromise the effectiveness of progestogen-only pills (POPs) such as missed pills, drug interactions, and vomiting or diarrhoea.
    • Situations which could result in unscheduled bleeding, such as:
      • Sexually transmitted infections (STIs) — as a minimum, test for Chlamydia trachomatis. The risk of STIs is increased if the woman is under 25 years, has a new sexual partner, or has had more than one sexual partner in the last year. For more information, see the CKS topic on Chlamydia - uncomplicated genital.
      • Pregnancy — perform a pregnancy test.
      • Gynaecological conditions such as cervical cancer — if this is suspected, refer the woman using a suspected cancer pathway referral (for an appointment within 2 weeks). For more information, see the CKS topic on Gynaecological cancers - recognition and referral.
      • Endometrial cancer — refer women aged 45 and older using a suspected cancer pathway referral (for an appointment within 2 weeks) if they have menstrual irregularities. Refer women younger than 45 years if they have risk factors for endometrial cancer and persistent, problematic bleeding after the first 3 months of use, or if they present with a change in bleeding pattern after at least 3 months of use. For more information, see the CKS topic on Gynaecological cancers - recognition and referral.
  • Consider performing a speculum and pelvic examination:
    • For persistent bleeding beyond the first 3 months of use — unscheduled bleeding is common in the first 3 months of starting a new hormonal contraceptive method.
    • For new symptoms or a change in bleeding after at least 3 months of use.
    • If the woman has not participated in the NHS Cervical Screening Programme regularly. For more information, see the CKS topic on Cervical cancer and HPV.
    • If requested by the woman.
    • If there are other symptoms such as pelvic pain, dyspareunia, or post-coital bleeding. 
  • If no other underlying cause of irregular bleeding is suspected, and speculum and pelvic examination is normal, the bleeding can be assumed to be caused by the POP. Providing the woman has no other symptoms:
    • Reassure her that unscheduled bleeding is common in POP users.
    • Advise her that although bleeding may settle with time, there is no evidence to indicate which women may become amenorrhoeic, or which women may experience persistent irregular bleeding, or for how this will continue. As a general guide, over 12 months' of use, over a 3-month interval:
      • 5 in 10 women will be amenorrhoeic or have infrequent bleeding.
      • 4 in 10 women will have 3–5 bleeding/spotting episodes (regular bleeding).
      • 1 in 10 women will have 6 or more bleeding/spotting episodes (frequent bleeding).
      • 2 in 10 women will have bleeding/spotting episodes lasting more than 14 days (prolonged bleeding).
    • If the bleeding is unacceptable to the woman, consider changing to:
      • A different POP, although there is no evidence that changing the progestogen type or dose improves bleeding.
      • A different type of contraceptive method. See the CKS topic on Contraception - assessment for information on other contraceptive methods.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
These recommendations are based on the Faculty of Sexual and Reproductive Healthcare (FSRH) clinical guidelines, Progestogen-only pills [FSRH, 2015a], Problematic bleeding with hormonal contraception [FSRH, 2015c], the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) guideline Suspected cancer: recognition and referral [NICE, 2015], and the manufacturer's Summary of Product Characteristics [ABPI, 2015a; ABPI, 2016a].

Endometrial cancer
  • NICE advises considering using a suspected cancer pathway referral (for an appointment within 2 weeks) for women aged under 55 years with post-menopausal bleeding. However, the FSRH advises that an endometrial biopsy should be considered in women aged 45 years or over and in women under 45 years with risk factors for endometrial cancer who have persistent problematic bleeding after the first 3 months of using a method, or who present with a change in bleeding pattern [NICE, 2015; FSRH, 2015c].

subChapters.htmlHeader: How effective are progestogen-only pills (POPs) at preventing pregnancy?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• For a comparison of the efficacy of progestogen-only pills (POPs) with other methods of contraception, see the section on Comparative efficacy in the CKS topic on Contraception - assessment.
    • When used perfectly (consistently and correctly), 0.3% of women will conceive within the first year of use due to method failure.
    • When used typically, 9% of women will conceive within the first year of use due to method failure or user failure.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent: This information is based on the Faculty of Sexual and Reproductive Healthcare (FSRH) clinical guideline Progestogen-only pills [FSRH, 2015a], and on expert opinion in the medical textbook Contraceptive technology [Hatcher, 2011].

subChapters.htmlHeader: What are the key drug interactions for progestogen-only pills?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
Liver enzyme-inducing drugs

  • Advise the woman that liver enzyme-inducing drugs may reduce the efficacy of progestogen–only pills (POPs). Examples of liver enzyme-inducing drugs are:
    • Antibiotics — rifampicin and rifabutin are very potent liver enzyme inducers.
    • Antiepileptic drugs such as carbamazepine, oxcarbazepine, phenytoin, barbiturates, primidone, and topiramate.
      • Topiramate is associated with a risk of fetal malformations and can impair the effectiveness of hormonal contraceptives. Before initiating topiramate in a woman of childbearing potential, pregnancy testing should be performed. The patient should be fully informed of the risks related to the use of topiramate during pregnancy. Ensure that women and girls of childbearing potential are advised that they should be using a highly effective method of contraception [ABPI, 2017]. 
    • Antiretrovirals such as ritonavir, ritonavir-boosted protease inhibitors, efavirenz, and nevirapine.
    • St John's wort — advise women taking the POP not to take herbal products containing St John’s wort.
  • If a woman is on short-term treatment (2 months or less) with a liver enzyme-inducing drug:
    • Advise her to stop the POP and change to an alternative contraceptive method unaffected by liver enzyme-inducing drugs.
      • For example having a one-off progestogen-only injection to cover the short-term treatment and for 28 days after.
    • If this is not acceptable or possible:
      • Continue the POP. 
      • Advise the woman to avoid sexual intercourse or use a barrier method of contraception (such as condoms) while taking, and for 28 days after stopping, the liver enzyme-inducing drug.
    • Consider the need for emergency contraception (EC) if unprotected sexual intercourse has taken place while the efficacy of the POP may have been reduced, for example if the woman has already started treatment with a liver enzyme-inducing drug. For more information, see the CKS topic on Contraception - emergency.
  • If a woman is on long-term treatment (more than 2 months) with a liver enzyme-inducing drug:
    • Advise her to change to an alternative contraceptive method unaffected by liver enzyme-inducing drugs (such as barrier methods or the progestogen-only injectable). 
    • Do not increase the dose of the POP.
    • Consider the need for EC if sexual intercourse has taken place while the efficacy of the POP may have been reduced, for example if the woman has already started treatment with a liver enzyme-inducing drug. For more information, see the CKS topic on Contraception - emergency.

Griseofulvin

  • Griseofulvin may reduce the contraceptive effect of POPs — advise the woman to change to an alternative method of contraception unaffected by griseofulvin. 

Lamotrigine

  • Lamotrigine increases plasma levels of progestogen — monitor for adverse effects of POP.

Ulipristal acetate (Esmya®)

  • Ulipristal acetate 5 mg (Esmya®) is licensed for the pre-operative treatment of moderate to severe symptoms of uterine fibroids. The dose (5 mg daily) is lower than that used for emergency contraception (30 mg as a one-off dose). The manufacturers of Esmya® advise avoiding concomitant use of POPs as they may reduce the efficacy of ulipristal.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent: These recommendations are based on the Faculty of Sexual and Reproductive Healthcare (FSRH) clinical guidelines, Progestogen-only pills [FSRH, 2015a], Drug interactions with hormonal contraception [FSRH, 2012; FSRH, 2017a], and the manufacturer's Summaries of Product Characteristics [ABPI, 2016a; ABPI, 2016b].

subChapters.htmlHeader: What follow up should I consider for a woman using a progestogen-only pill (POP)?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Arrange follow up 10–12 weeks after the first prescription of a progestogen-only pill (POP) and then at least every 12 months thereafter, provided there are no troublesome adverse effects.
  • At the follow up visit:
    • Check the woman's blood pressure and body mass index.
    • Assess the woman for any new risk factors that may mean this method is no longer suitable. For more information, see the topic on Contraception - assessment. 
    • Ask about any adverse effects. 
    • Check that the woman is taking the POP correctly and consistently.
    • Check her knowledge of what to do if a pill is missed.
    • Remind her about possible drug interactions.
  • Offer verbal and/or written advice on long-acting reversible contraception (copper intrauterine device, levonorgestrel intrauterine system, progestogen-only injectables, progestogen-only implant, and the combined hormonal vaginal ring). For more information, see the CKS topics on Contraception - IUS/IUD and Contraception - combined hormonal methods.

subChapters.htmlHeader: How long should the progestogen-only pill (POP) be used for?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• If the woman is not amenorrhoeic, continue the progestogen-only pill (POP) over 55 years of age until she has been amenorrhoeic for 1 year. 
  • If the woman is amenorrhoeic, consider one of the following options:
    • For a woman over the age of 50 years, check serum follicle stimulating hormone (FSH) levels on two occasions, with an interval of 6 weeks between tests. If both FSH levels are more than 30 IU/L, stop the POP after a further year.
    • Continue the POP until the age of 55 years if required and requested.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent: These recommendations are based on the Faculty of Sexual and Reproductive Healthcare (FSRH) clinical guidelines Progestogen-only pills [FSRH, 2015a], Contraception for women aged over 40 years [FSRH, 2010b] and expert opinion in a medical textbook, Contraception today [Guillebaud, 2016].
